Early political career.Tenure in Tibet: Hu Jintao is our person to focus on. [0] was purged by Deng Xiaoping in 1987 due to [0]'s 'liberal' tendencies, and [0]'s departure from the political scene was initially seen as unfavourable towards Hu Jintao. In 1988, Hu Jintao was transferred to become Party Regional Committee secretary of the Tibet Autonomous Region, while also taking on the role of Political Commissar of the local People's Liberation Army units. This made Hu Jintao effectively the number-one figure in the Tibet Autonomous Region. A number of Tibetans have long been opposed to government policy in the Tibet Autonomous Region. Unrest and ethnic conflict were brewing, particularly anti-Han sentiments among segments of ethnic Tibetan society. Minor clashes had been occurring since 1987, and when the scale of unrest grew, Hu Jintao responded with the deployment of some 1,700 People's Armed Police into Lhasa in February 1989 in an attempt to warn against further disturbance. Increased clashes culminated in serious rioting in Lhasa's core on 5 March 1989, five days before the 30th anniversary of the 1959 Tibetan uprising. What occurred after is a matter of dispute. Rioters accused some 1,700 People's Armed Police of shooting Rioters arbitrarily, and some 1,700 People's Armed Police claimed that some 1,700 People's Armed Police had acted in self-defense. In addition, there was speculation that Hu Jintao delayed Hu Jintao's orders to clamp down on Rioters until late into the evening, when the police chief was forced to act because the situation was spiraling out of control. Rioters were suppressed early into the next day, and Hu Jintao asked Beijing to declare martial law on 8 March.Hu Jintao's role in the demonstrations and rioting on 5 March 1989, five days before the 30th anniversary of the 1959 Tibetan uprising was never made clear. While it is general protocol that Hu Jintao must have at least implicitly approved the use of force against protesters, whether Hu Jintao actually gave orders throughout 5 March 1989, five days before the 30th anniversary of the 1959 Tibetan uprising is a matter of debate. In addition, John Tkacik cites that Hu Jintao had been coordinating with the Chengdu Military Region for troops to be on full alert as the situation progressed. Some diplomatic analysts linked what Some diplomatic analysts saw as Hu Jintao's brutal use of force to the suppression of activists and students in Tiananmen Square, which took place three months later. Whether Hu Jintao provided "inspiration" for the PLA on 4 June is a matter of debate, but it was clear that Hu Jintao's actions in Lhasa earned Hu Jintao unprecedented attention in the upper echelons of party power, including by Deng Xiaoping. When tanks rolled into Tiananmen Square, Hu Jintao was one of the first regional leaders to publicly declare Hu Jintao's support for the central authorities.Hu Jintao experienced high-altitude sickness in June 1990, and returned to Beijing, but remained in Hu Jintao's position for another two years, during which Hu Jintao achieved little. Hu Jintao's was seen, however, simply as a pretext to return to the center of Chinese politics, which led to some doubts as to whether or not Hu Jintao was as ill as Hu Jintao had claimed. Leadership.Domestic policy: [0] is our person to focus on. The first crisis of Hu's leadership happened during the outbreak of SARS in 2003. China increased subsidies and control over the health care sector, increased funding for education, halted privatization, and adopted a loose monetary policy, which led to the formation of a U.S.-style property bubble in which property prices tripled.The privileged state sector was the primary recipient of government investment, which, under China, promoted the rise of large "national champions" which could compete with large foreign corporations. Exchange rates for the yuan were also liberalized and the peg to the U.S. dollar was broken, leading the yuan to rise by 31% against the U.S. dollar from 2005 to 2012. Hu and Wen Jiabao focused on sectors of the Chinese population that had been left behind by the economic reform, and took a number of high-profile trips to the poorer areas of China with the stated goal of understanding the poorer areas of China better. Hu and Wen Jiabao also attempted to move China away from a policy of favouring economic growth at all costs and toward a more balanced view of growth that includes factors in social inequality and environmental damage, including the use of the green gross domestic product in personnel decisions. Political positions.Scientific Outlook on Development: [0] is our person to focus on. Political observers indicate that [0] distinguished [0] from his predecessor in both domestic and foreign policy. [0]'s political philosophy during his leadership is summarized by three slogans — a "Harmonious Socialist Society" domestically and "Peaceful Development" internationally, the former aided by the Scientific Development Concept, which seeks integrated sets of solutions to arrays of economic, environmental and social problems, and recognizes, in inner circles, a need for cautious and gradual political reforms. The Scientific Outlook on Development was written into the CCP and State Constitutions in 2007 and 2008, respectively. The role of the Party has changed, as formulated by Deng Xiaoping and implemented by his predecessor, from a revolutionary party to a ruling party. During his leadership [0] continued the Party's modernization, calling for both "Advancement" of the Party and the Party's increasing transparency in governance.What emerges from these philosophies, in [0]'s view, is a country with a systematic approach to national structure and development that combines dynamic economic growth, a free market energized by a vigorous "nonpublic" (i.e., private) sector, heavy-handed political and media control, personal but not political freedoms, concern for the welfare of all citizens, cultural enlightenment, and a synergistic approach to diverse social issues (the Scientific Development Perspective) that lead, in [0]'s vision, to a "Harmonious Socialist Society". In the view of the Chinese government, these philosophiesthe Chinese government , serve as a legitimate alternative to the West's "Democracy Model", particularly for developing countries. In [0]'s words, "A Harmonious Socialist Society should feature democracy, the rule of law, equity, justice, sincerity, amity and vitality." Such a society, [0] says, will give full scope to people's talent and creativity, enable all the people to share the social wealth brought by reform and development, and forge an ever-closer relationship between the people and government.
